arguments.name: Pursuer had right to animal
arguments.context: Post, the pursuer, had no right to the fox: "The foregoing authorities are decisive to show that mere pursuit gave Post no legal right to the fox, but that he became the property of Pierson, who intercepted and killed him."

arguments.name: Pursuer not in possession
arguments.context: Pursuer was not in possession of the fox.

arguments.name: Animals not confined by owner
arguments.context: The fox is a wild animal and was not confined by anyone.

arguments.name: Effort promising success made to secure animal made by pursuer
arguments.context: Post pursued the fox with his own hounds and was "on the point of seizing his prey."

arguments.name: Pursuit not enough
arguments.context: The court opinion, written by Tompkins, cited Justinian's Institutes to argue that pursuit alone, even with wounding, is insufficient to establish ownership unless the animal is actually taken.

arguments.name: Mere pursuit is not enough
arguments.context: Written by Tompkins: "Mere pursuit gave Post no legal right to the fox."

arguments.name: Justinian is too old an authority
arguments.context: Livingston dissented: "Whatever Justinian may have thought... his code was compiled many hundred years ago... it would be very hard indeed... not to have a right to establish a rule for ourselves."

arguments.name: Bodily seizure is not necessary, reasonable prospect of capture is enough
arguments.context: Livingston, quoting Barbeyrac, argued that property in wild animals can be acquired without physical seizure if the pursuer had a reasonable prospect of capturing the animal.

arguments.name: The land was open
arguments.context: The hunt occurred "on waste and uninhabited ground."

arguments.name: Not for courts to regulate competition
arguments.context: The court warned that ruling otherwise would open the door to excessive litigation, implying courts should not regulate such competitive conduct.

defeats.annotation: Arguing Post did not possess the fox
Promising efforts to catch the fox rather than in possession can already help establish the fox's ownership
Promising efforts to catch the fox rather than confining it can already help establish the fox's ownership
According to Justinian, pursuit is not enough to establish the right to the animal
pursuit is not enough to establish the right to the animal
Judge Tompkins points out that pursuit with a reasonable prospect of capture is not enough to establish the right to the animal
Quoting from Justinian is not appropriate, as it is too old an authority
Judge Livingston cited Barbeyrac, claiming that a reasonable prospect of capture is enough
Judge Livingston cited Barbeyrac, claiming that a reasonable prospect of capture is enough
